step.context: \text{Which of the following correctly shows }\\ \dfrac{2}{\left(1-x\right)\left(1+x^2\right)} \text{ as the sum of partial fractions?}
step.reason: \text{If in a proper rational function, }\dfrac{P \left(x\right)}{\left(x-a\right)Q \left(x\right)},\\ Q \left(x\right)\text{ cannot be partitioned - like }1+x^2 \text{ can't.}\\ \text{Then the function is expressed as }\\ \dfrac{P \left(x\right)}{\left(x-a\right)Q \left(x\right)} = \dfrac{A}{x-a}+\dfrac{Bx+C}{Q \left(x\right)}

\dfrac{2}{\left(1-x\right)\left(1+x^2\right)}=\dfrac{A}{1-x}+\dfrac{Bx+C}{1+x^2}\\ \implies 2 = A \left(1+x^2\right)+\left(Bx+C\right)\left(1-x\right)\\ \qquad= \left(A -B \right)x^2 +\left(B - C\right)x +\left(A +C\right)\\ \therefore A -B =0, B -C =0 \text{ and } A +C =2\\ \text{Which gives }A =B =C =1

\text{Z is simply a standard result }\\ -\int \dfrac{dx}{1+x^2} =\tan^{-1} x +C\\ \text{In Y, put }t =1+X^2 \implies x.dx = \dfrac{dt}{2}\\ \text{And in X, if }t = 1-x\text{, then }dx = -dt\\ \implies \int \dfrac{dx}{1-x} = -\int \dfrac{dt}{t} = -\log \left|t\right| = -\log \left|1-x\right|
